Research article Easily synthesized self-nitrogen doped carbon-supported nickel bio-based sustainable catalyst for hydrogenation of benzylamine from benzonitrile Weidong Liu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Jianguo Liu Writing – review & editing Resources Methodology Investigation Funding acquisition Formal analysis Data curation ⁎ School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China School of Energy and Environment Southeast University Nanjing 210096 China School of Energy and Environment, Southeast University, Nanjing 210096, China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Benzylamine production from the hydrogenation of nitrile is attractive, but most of the catalysts are complicated and costly. In this paper, a simple synthesis of self-nitrogen-doped carbon-supported nickel biobased sustainable catalyst (Ni-JKS-600) for benzylamine hydrogenation with benzonitrile has been reported. The catalyst has high specific surface area, abundant micro-mesoporous structure and nickel hydrogenation active site. By optimizing the reaction conditions, a mild reaction condition (120 ℃, 2 MPa H2, 3 h) was determined, and it was found that the solvent had a significant effect on the selectivity of benzylamine, and the selectivity of benzylamine could reach 97.08 % when ammonia methanol was used as the solvent. Ni-JKS-600 catalyst is superior to precious metal catalysts (Ru, Pt, Ir, Pd) in aniline selectivity, and is comparable to Raney nickel catalyst, which shows its potential application in industrial production of amines. The catalyst uses cheap and widely available chitin as carbon and nitrogen source, and has the characteristics of green economy with simple preparation method and low cost. It is expected to replace precious metal catalyst for efficient production of benzylamine in the future. Keywords Chitin Hydrogenation Benzonitrile Primary amine Nickel catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Amines are common intermediates and precursors in the preparation of dyes, drugs, anti-corrosion inhibitors, agrochemicals, industrial synthetic polymers, and catalysts [1–7]. Of all amines, primary amines are the most valuable intermediates because they could further undergo derivatization reactions to give secondary or tertiary amines [8,9]. Therefore, the huge demand for primary amine synthesis has been widely investigated by researchers. The methods for the synthesis of primary amines include reduction amination of carbonyl compounds [10–12], reduction of nitro compounds [13], amination of alkyl halides, and direct amination of alcohols [14,15]. However, it still faces the challenge of harsh reaction conditions, poor activity, and low selectivity. Recently, researchers have found that hydrogenation of nitrile catalyzed by hydrogen molecules is an efficient, green one-step method for the synthesis of high-value-added amines [6,16–18]. However, the hydrogenation of nitrile has a big problem with product selectivity uncertainties. In the process of reaction, by-products such as tertiary and secondary amines are inevitably produced, resulting in the high cost of subsequent product separation [19,20]. Several literature works investigated the homogeneous method which showed relatively good performance in the hydrogenation of nitrile. However, it is difficult to separate and recover the catalysts, and it would cause serious metal pollution, which limits its wide application in commercial development. Heterogeneous catalysts are widely used in the hydrogenation of nitrile due to their characteristics of easy separation, low cost, and large-scale development potential [3,21]. For example, various metal-based catalysts (including Pd, Pt, Ru, Ni, Co, Cu, Rh, Fe, etc.) have been successfully applied to nitrile hydrogenation reactions [22–30]. The metal itself is inherently selective for nitrile hydrogenation, and in general, Co, Ni, and Ru series catalysts mainly generate primary amines [31,32]. Compared with precious metal catalysts, non-precious metals are more and more favored by researchers because of their abundant reserves and low cost. It was reported that several cobalt catalytic systems exhibit high catalytic performance for the reaction under milder reaction conditions. For example, Matthias Beller et al. developed a novel heterogeneous cobalt catalyst system on α-Al2O3. This cobalt catalyst facilitates the formation of primary amines from nitriles [31]. Liu et al. described the first cobalt-catalyzed transfer hydrogenation of nitriles for a chemodivergent synthesis of primary and secondary amines [16]. Kathrin Junge et al. have developed a Co catalyst with an aliphatic PNP pincer ligand for the reduction of aromatic and aliphatic nitriles to primary amines [9]. And Co/SiO2 acted as an effective and reusable heterogeneous catalyst for selective primary amine synthesis [27]. Zhang et al. utilized a cobalt/tetraphosphine complex to catalyze hydrogenative transformation of nitriles [33]. Researchers have been actively focusing on nickel-based catalysts due to the low price and good hydrogenation performance of nickel [6,34,35], and Raney Nickel has been widely used in the nitrile hydrogenation industry due to its good catalytic activity. However, Raney Nickel is extremely flammable and could cause serious accidents in laboratories. Hence, Raney Nickel should be treated in a strictly inert atmosphere, usually stored in water as a suspension, which further complicates the precise measurement of the catalyst [36]. Therefore, the development of nickel-based catalysts with good activity and safety has raised concerns for industrial applications. Cao et al. prepared a layered double hydroxide (LDH) coated nickel-based core–shell composite with a benzylamine selectivity of 76.1 % at 373 K [37]. Segobia et al. achieved a high benzonitrile conversion and a selectivity of 92 % on silica-supported Ni catalyst at 373 K and 13 bar H2 [38]. Shi et al. prepared a bimetallic catalyst supported by mixed oxides, and the yield of amylamine reached 70.8 % when the reaction temperature was 130 ℃ [39]. Zhao et al. reported non-precious zinc and aluminum oxides supported Ni catalysts (Ni/ZnAlOx) at room temperature, which resulted in the conversion and selectivity of benzylamine was 57.1 % and 91.1 %, respectively [1]. Ma et al. reported that silica-supported ultra-small nickel nanoparticles, as one of the most common heterogeneous catalysts, could hydrogenate a variety of nitriles to primary amines in high selection under mild conditions [34]. Zhang et al. prepared a nitrogen-doped carbon-supported nickel catalyst with a primary amine yield of 89.5 % at 80 ℃ and 2.5 MPa H2 [40]. Although researchers have reported a large number of related nickel-supported catalyst studies, the development of simple preparation methods, low-cost metal-supported synthetic catalysts, especially sustainable bio-based carbon support, is still of great significance. In this study, a nitrogen-doped carbon-supported non-noble metal nickel catalyst (Ni-JKS-600) was prepared by calcination at 600 ℃ for 3 h in a tube furnace with Chitin as the only nitrogen and carbon sources and nickel acetate tetrahydrate as the metal salt precursor. Chitin is the second most abundant polysaccharide in nature (behind only cellulose), with an estimated 1 billion tons of chitin produced each year in the biosphere. Chitin is widely available and inexpensive, making it a promising biomass model compound. On the one hand, although traditional Ru, Pt and other precious metal catalysts are highly active, they are expensive and prone to excessive hydrogenation (such as secondary amine formation), while Raney nickel has a high flammable risk. On the other hand, undoped carbon-loaded Ni catalysts usually require additives (such as Al2O3) or harsh conditions (high pressure/high temperature) to achieve high selectivity, while nitrogen-doped carbon achieves the same selectivity as precious metals through its electronic regulation and structural characteristics, at a lower cost. Using chitin as carbon and nitrogen source not only has low cost, but also conforms to the principle of green chemistry. Nitrogen-doped carbon produced from the pyrolysis of chitin has abundant nitrogen functional groups (such as pyridine nitrogen and graphite nitrogen), which is an ideal precursor for the synthesis of nitrogen-doped carbon. The work in this paper mainly includes two parts: firstly, a simple and low-cost method applied for catalyst synthesis was developed. Secondly, the factors related to the activity and selectivity of benzonitrile hydrogenation were investigated. The catalytic performance of benzylamine was analyzed in detail from the aspects of reaction temperature, pressure, time, catalyst loadings, stirring speed and solvent. In the hydrogenation process, ammonia plays an important regulatory role in inhibiting the formation of intermediates and self-coupling. In general, this green economy, simple preparation catalyst has potential application prospects in the future efficient production of the benzylamine industry, which is expected to become a substitute for precious metal catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Chitin ((C8H13NO5)n, practical grade), Nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O, AR, 99 %), and benzylamine(AR, 99 %) were purchased from Aladdin (Shanghai) Chemical Technology Co., Ltd.; Ethanol absolute(AR) and methanol(AR) were provided by Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.; Benzonitrile and Raney® nickel catalyst(100 meshes) were obtained from Meryer (Shanghai) Chemical Technology Co., Ltd.; Ammonia methanol(NH3, 2/4/7 mol/L in MeOH, EnergySeal) was acquired from Anhui Zesheng Technology Co., Ltd.; High purity nitrogen(≥99.999 %) and high purity hydrogen(≥99.999 %) were obtained from Nanjing Special Gas Plant Co., Ltd.; deionized water (σ < 5 μS m−1) was self-made in the laboratory. All chemical reagents were analytically pure and were used without any purification. 2.2 Preparation of Ni-JKS-600 catalysts 4.98 g nickel(II) acetate tetrahydrate (Ni(CH3COO)2·4H2O, 0.02 mol) and 4.06 g chitin ((C8H13NO5)n, 0.02 mol) were dissolved in 80 mL anhydrous ethanol, and then the mixture was stirred in oil bath at 70 °C (300 rpm) for 4 h, and placed in a drying oven at 100 °C for 24 h. The dried samples were then placed in a small porcelain boat and calcined under a high purity N2(99.999 %) atmosphere of 50 mL min−1 in a tubular furnace at 600 ℃ for 3 h at a heating rate of 5 ℃ min−1. After the reaction, the catalyst was cooled to room temperature and named Ni-JKS-600. 2.3 Characterization of catalysts The SEM images were obtained on a Sirion field emission scanning electron microscope (FEI) operated at 10 kV. The nitrogen adsorption isotherms were measured using the BET method on the Quadrasorb SI nitrogen Adsorption Instrument (Quantachrome, USA) at −196 ℃. The specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst were determined by the Micrometritics ASAP 2010 automatic physical adsorption instrument. The catalyst was vacuum dried for 8 h, and the temperature was maintained at 160 ℃. N2 physical adsorption test BET specific surface area, calculated by using the adsorption data of relative pressure (P/Po) in the range of 0.05–0.25 (R2 > 0.999, C > 0). The total pore volume is obtained by taking P/Po = 0.99 adsorption capacity. The micropore volume is calculated by t-plot method. The mesoporous volume is obtained by subtracting the micropore volume from the total pore volume. The data was processed by ASiQwin software. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken on Talos F200X(Thermo Fisher Scientific, America) with an operating voltage of 200 kV. The sample preparation method characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was ultrasonic catalyst dispersed in ethanol for 10 min, dripped on 300 mesh copper mesh, and dried at room temperature. No additional processing was performed to avoid changing the state of the sample before the micrograph was obtained. Before the X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis test, the powder sample is pressed into the glass sample tank to ensure a smooth surface. The test environment was normal temperature and pressure, and the catalyst was not pre-reduced to maintain the original state. The X-ray diffraction pattern (XRD) was analyzed on X'Pert Pro MPD (Smartlab, Japan) using the Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA, with a range of 2θ from 5° to 80°(scanning rate is 10°/min). Processing and assignments of the powder patterns were conducted on the software Jade 6.0 using the Powder Diffraction File (PDF) database of the International Centre of Diffraction Data (ICDD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Escalab 250 Xi, USA) analyzed the elemental valence information. The charge correction of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) test is based on the binding energy calibration of the C1s peak (284.8 eV). Shirley background deduction was used for baseline fitting, and 70 % Gauss-30 % Lorentz mixture function was used for peak fitting (Avantage software). 2.4 Catalyst activity test The hydrogenation reaction was carried out in a batch reactor (Shanghai Yanzheng Instrument Co., Ltd.), which had six independent 20 mL wells. A glass lining containing 0.5 mmol benzonitrile, 20 mg catalyst, 5 mL solvent, and a magnetic agitated rotor were placed in the well. Then, under the condition of the pressure of 4 MPa, the reactor was sealed and H2 replaced three times, the air was drained, and the experimental target H2 pressure was pressurized. The stirring speed was set to 500 rpm, and the reactor was preheated from room temperature to reaction temperature at a rate of 3 °C min−1. The reaction was carried out at the reaction temperature for the required time. After the reaction, it was naturally cooled to room temperature, and the remaining gas in the reactor was discharged. The reaction solution was collected by a dropper and filtered by a filter membrane(Φ13mm*0.22 μm, Nylon 66, JinTeng). The reaction product was tested by gas chromatography (GC). The conversion of the substrate and the selectivity of the target product were calculated. Each experiment was repeated three times, and the average value was taken with an error not exceeding ± 5 %. 2.5 Methods for product analysis By using the area normalization method, the distribution of products was analyzed by GC-2014C (Shimadzu, Japan) with an HP5 column(30 m × 250 mm × 0.25 μm) and an FID detector. 3 Results anddiscussion 3.1 Synthesis andCharacterizations ofNi-JKS-600 catalysts. The surface morphology and structure of the catalyst were observed by SEM and TEM images. Supplementary Information(SI, Figure S1 ) showed some representative scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of a non-noble metal nickel catalyst (Ni-JKS-600). As observed in SI Fig. S1 a-b, the surface of the Ni-JKS-600 catalyst had an obvious pore structure with the Ni particles dispersed evenly. The surface of the catalyst shows abundant micro-mesoporous structures that are cross-linked to each other, implying its hierarchical structure. Further high-resolution (HR) TEM clearly showed that the graphene layer structure of the catalyst with lattice stripes (Fig. 1 a-b). The white spots are the presence of Ni that can be observed in the selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern of the Ni-JKS-600 catalyst. According to the inset of Fig. 1 b, the metal Ni nanoparticles were well dispersed on the surface of the carbon, not only had the (200) plane of the Ni but also had the (111) plane for the Ni with d-spacing of 0.20 nm. Defect sites of nitrogen-doped carbon (such as pyridine nitrogen) can be used as anchoring sites to evenly disperse Ni nanoparticles, prevent metal agglomeration and improve catalytic efficiency. The corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) maps showed that the C, Ni, O, and N atoms were distributed homogeneously over the catalyst (Fig. 1 c–g). The load on the nickel element can also be seen in Fig. S2 . The pore structure and specific surface area were determined by the N2 adsorption–desorption measurements (Fig. 2 a). The prepared catalyst exhibits a typical type-II isotherm with a hysteresis loop in the relative pressure zones of 0.45–1.0 (P/P0), indicating their meso-structural features. At very low relative pressure, the adsorption capacity rises rapidly. It indicated that the catalyst is endowed with abundant microstructures. The pore distribution including micropores (Smicro) and mesopores (Smeso) was determined using the t-plot method. The total specific surface area of the catalyst is 261.20 m2 g−1, the area contributed by micropores is 143.12 m2g−1, the area contributed by mesoporous pores is 118.08 m2g−1 and the pore volume of micropores is 0.06 cm3g−1. All these indicate that the catalyst has an abundant micro-mesoporous structure. The results of BET were in accordance with the SEM analysis. The large surface area and abundant porous structure are very helpful for chemical reactions because the reaction molecules and products can move freely between the reaction solvent and the active site on the surface of the Ni-JKS-600 catalyst. This rich micro-mesoporous structure not only exists in the main body of the catalyst but also extends into the graphene layers, providing channels for benzonitrile molecules to diffuse to the nickel active sites, ensuring the smooth progress of the reaction. As reported in the previous literature, the graphene formation could further be confirmed by the XRD analysis. As shown in the XRD spectra (Fig. 2 b), the peaks located at approximately 26°, correspond to the C(0 0 2) lattice plane, which are indicators of the graphite hexagonal carbon layers. This is also consistent with the above-mentioned TEM analysis and the XRD results reported in the literature. The Ni-JKS-600 catalyst had the peaks of Ni (111), Ni (200), and Ni (2 2 0) metal species which agreed with the TEM analysis [40]. The presence of graphene and Ni has been shown to be effective in improving the catalytic performance. The graphene shell is a strong substrate that can completely encapsulate the encased metal Ni, thereby physically isolating the metal from the reaction environment. In this regard, further observation of the XRD images ( Fig. S3 ) after the catalyst reaction shows that the Ni atoms fully encased in the graphene shell are still present as the crystalline phases of Ni (111), Ni (200) and Ni (220). No metal leaching was detected in the liquid after the reaction(SI, Table S2 ). Further, the corresponding characteristic peaks can be observed from the Raman spectrogram, in which the D peak (∼1350 cm−1) corresponds to the defects in the carbon material, indicating that there are structural defects in the material. The G-peak (∼1576 cm−1) corresponds to the in-plane vibration of sp2 hybrid carbon atoms, reflecting the order of graphitized carbon. 2D peaks (∼2700 cm−1) indicate more defects. The strength ratio of peak D to peak G (ID/IG) can be used to assess the degree of defect of the material. As shown in the Fig. S6 , the high ID/IG (1.02) indicates that the carbon material in the catalyst is nanocrystalline with abundant defects, which is consistent with the conclusion of wide peaks (small crystals) in XRD. So, the graphene shell is not fully dense but contains defects and micropores. These defects create pathways for reactant diffusion while still protecting Ni from bulk oxidation. To further determine the compositions and chemical states of the elements, XPS was performed in Fig. 3 . The full survey scan of Ni-JKS-600 showed the presence of C, N, O and Ni elements (Fig. 3 a). As shown in Fig. 3 b, the high-resolution C 1s spectra can be divided into four peaks located at 284.8, 286, 289.3 and 291.66 eV, corresponding to the C–C/C=C, C–N, C=O and O-C=O bonds, respectively [12]. The N 1 s spectra of the catalyst, which can be further deconvoluted into two peaks, are assigned to the pyridinic-N (∼398.7 eV, 36.37 %) and graphitic-N (∼401.2 eV, 63.63 %) (Fig. 3 c). Enhanced metal-carrier interactions, pyridinic nitrogen (Pyridinic-N) and graphitic-N (Graphitic-N) are two common forms of nitrogen-doped carbon. Pyridine nitrogen forms a stable active site by interacting with the d orbital of Ni. The graphite nitrogen regulates the electronic state of Ni through electron transfer, inhibiting excessive hydrogenation or side reactions (such as self-condensation of imines). XPS measurement indicated that both metallic Ni0 and Ni2+ species existed on the catalyst surface (Fig. 3 d) [41]. In addition, a peak with a binding energy of 859.9 eV was also observed, which was the satellite peak of nickel [42]. It is well known that when pyridinic-N species interact with metal atoms, a positive binding energy shift could be observed. In addition, graphite-N has been shown to be an active substance for catalysts. The graphitic-N species donates electrons to neighboring metal atoms which results in the negative shift of the binding energy. The change in Ni electron density could affect its catalytic reactivity and selectivity. The graphene shell encapsulating Ni nanoparticles is porous due to nitrogen-doped defects (pyridinic-N and graphitic-N), allowing selective diffusion of organic substrates like benzonitrile while mitigating O2 penetration. 3.2 Ni-JKS-600 catalyzed selective hydrogenation ofbenzonitrile in the batch reactor 3.2.1 Influence of the solvent According to previous research, in the process of hydrogenation of nitrile, the solvents mainly used are alcohol, liquid ammonia, water, or alkanes. Because different solvents have different properties, the catalytic performance of the Ni-JKS-600 catalyst will be affected. It is worth noting that the selectivity measurements cannot be compared at ∼ 100 % conversion, because, near 100 % conversion, any kinetics information in the system is lost due potential variations in reactive intermediate concentrations that occur at large extents of reaction. So, solvent effects, which are inherently kinetic, will not manifest themselves accurately at 100 % conversion [43]. Reactivity measurements reporting on kinetic phenomena must be performed at low conversion and in the absence of parasitic effects such as transport limitations or product inhibition. Methanol(MeOH), ethanol(EtOH), iso-propyl alcohol(IPA), ammonia methanol(AMeOH), deionized water(DW), dichloromethane(DCM), and tetrahydrofuran(THF) were used as solvents in this experiment. We tested the conversion rates and selectivity of different solvents under low conversion rates (＜30 %). As shown in Fig. 4 , the influence of different solvents on conversion varies significantly. When DW is used as the solvent, the conversion rate is the highest (∼80 %), whereas with DCM and THF, conversion remains low (<5%). This indicates that solvent properties play a crucial role in the reaction progression, likely due to interactions between the solvent, reactants, and catalyst—such as solvent polarity and solubility—which affect reactant distribution and reactivity in the system. Notably, when AMeOH is used as the solvent, selectivity reaches ∼ 90 %, significantly higher than other solvents. This further confirms its ability to stabilize key reaction intermediates and suppress side reactions. In contrast, other solvents like MeOH, EtOH, and IPA exhibit relatively low and similar selectivity (∼5–10 %), suggesting that side reactions are more prevalent or that these solvents weakly promote the formation of the target product. These findings highlight the critical role of solvents in determining product selectivity. Different solvents may alter reaction pathways or intermediate stability, thereby influencing selectivity toward the desired product. Although the selectivity obtained at a high conversion rate has limitations, it can still serve as a reference for industrial applications. The experimental results are shown in Table S1 . We further analyze the solvent effect by combining factors such as dielectric constant (polarity), hydrogen bonding capacity and viscosity of the solvent. The solvents used in the study (MeOH, EtOH, IPA, AMeOH, DW, THF) are polar, with dielectric constants (ε) as follows: MeOH (32.7), EtOH (24.3), IPA (18.3), AMeOH (∼33, similar to MeOH), DW (80.1), and THF (7.6). DCM (ε = 8.9) is weakly polar but uniquely problematic due to C-Cl bond hydrogenolysis under reaction conditions, generating Cl* species that poison Ni catalysts. Further analysis of hydrogen-bonding ability of binding solvents shows that protic solvents (MeOH, EtOH, IPA, AMeOH) stabilize imine intermediates through hydrogen bonding, but methanol lacks NH3, leading to a side reaction. Alcohol is similar to methanol, but its steric resistance increases and decreases selectivity. Only NH3 containing AMeOH can further inhibit the condensation side reaction and increase selectivity. Aprotic solvents (THF, DCM) lack hydrogen bond donors, and the intermediate stability is poor, resulting in reduced selectivity. The strong polarity of water leads to hydrolysis side reaction, and the selectivity is 0. Low viscosity solvents (MeOH, AMeOH, THF) have higher reaction efficiency. Isopropyl alcohol significantly limited mass transfer due to its high viscosity (2.04 cP), and the conversion rate was only 46 %. Therefore, we have conducted additional experiments by varying the stirring speed to assess mass transfer limitations. As shown in the Fig. S4 b, at a stirring speed of 300 rpm, the conversion rate remains relatively low (∼7%). When the stirring speed is increased to 500 rpm, the conversion rate rises to approximately 9 %. Further increasing the stirring speed to 700 rpm and 900 rpm results in no significant improvement in conversion, maintaining a level similar to that at 500 rpm. This indicates that within a certain range (300–500 rpm), increasing the stirring speed enhances the conversion rate, likely because faster mixing promotes better contact between reactants and the catalyst, thereby accelerating the reaction. However, once the stirring speed exceeds 500 rpm, further increases have negligible effects on conversion, suggesting that mass transfer is no longer the rate-limiting step, and diffusion limitations can be considered eliminated. Regarding selectivity, fluctuations remain minimal across different stirring speeds, consistently ranging between 8 %–9%. This demonstrates that stirring speed has little influence on product selectivity. The reaction system maintains a stable ability to generate the target product under varying stirring conditions, and changes in stirring speed do not significantly alter the reaction's selectivity pathway. Combining the solvent effects under different conversion rates, the conclusion obtained is consistent. The solvent performance ranking is: Ammonia Methanol (AMeOH) ≫ Methanol ≈ Ethanol > Tetrahydrofuran > Isopropanol > Water > Dichloromethane, where NH3 incorporation and low viscosity are critical for achieving both high conversion and selectivity [40]. Through the screening of the solvent system, in subsequent experiments, ammonia methanol was selected as the solvent. 3.2.2 Influence of the reaction pressure In the batch reactor hydrogenation reaction, the mass transfer of hydrogen on the catalyst surface is the key factor controlling the reaction rate, which is directly related to the partial pressure of hydrogen [44,45]. According to the experimental results (Fig. 5 ), when the reaction pressure is 0.5 MPa, the conversion rate of BN is only 71.8 %, and the selectivity of BA is 78.9 %. When the reaction pressure is 1 MPa, the conversion of BN is 89.02 %, and the selectivity of BA is 87.97 %. When the hydrogen pressure is increased to 2 MPa, the conversion of BN is ∼ 99 %, and the selectivity of BA reaches 96.46 %. After further increasing the hydrogen pressure, it was found that the selectivity of the target product did not change much with the increase in pressure. This indicates that mass transfer of hydrogen is not a rate limiting factor as the reaction pressure increases. The experimental evidence confirms that benzonitrile hydrogenation followsNi surface-mediated kinetics, with the reaction rate being governed bycatalytic surface processesrather than mass transfer limitations (H2 availability or reactant diffusion through graphene layers). Considering the safety problem, 2.0 MPa was the most appropriate reaction pressure. 3.2.3 Influence of the reaction temperature The suitable reaction temperature can accelerate the reaction speed of condensation and hydrogenation, and improve the selectivity of BA. Therefore, the effect of temperature on the reaction was studied (Fig. 6 ). The results show that the conversion and selectivity are improved with the increase in reaction temperature. When the temperature is 100 ℃, the conversion of BN is only 76.03 %, possibly due to thermodynamic reasons, the reaction is incomplete. When the temperature reaches 120 ℃, the conversion of BN is ∼ 99 %, and the selectivity of BA is 96.46 %. The elevated reaction temperature (120 °C) not only accelerates the reaction rate but also provides sufficient kinetic energy for benzonitrile molecules to overcome diffusion resistance, enabling more efficient diffusion to the nickel active sites on the catalyst surface. Further increasing the temperature, the performance improvement is not obvious. Considering the actual cost, the reaction temperature was finally determined to be 120 ℃. 3.2.4 Influence of solvent concentration of ammonia methanol According to the mechanism of benzonitrile hydrogenation reported in the literature, the hydrogenation of benzonitrile is prone to produce other by-products, which affect the formation of benzylamine. Adding ammonia to the reaction can effectively inhibit the side reaction and improve the selectivity of benzylamine. To further compare the effect of different molar concentrations of ammonia methanol, 2 mol/L, 4 mol/L, and 7 mol/L ammonia methanol were selected as solvents. The experimental results are shown in Fig. 7 . As the concentration of AMeOH increased from 2 mol/L to 7 mol/L, the conversion rate showed an upward trend. At 2 mol/L, the conversion rate was relatively low at approximately 30 %. When the concentration increased to 4 mol/L, the conversion rate rose to about 45 %. Upon reaching 7 mol/L, the conversion rate further improved to nearly 60 %. This indicates that increasing the AMeOH concentration promotes the reaction progress, thereby accelerating the reaction rate and enhancing the degree of reactant conversion. Moreover, at 7 mol/L AMeOH concentration, the selectivity for the target product was higher. The presence of higher NH3 concentration effectively suppresses the occurrence of side reactions. In summary, appropriately increasing the AMeOH concentration not only facilitates the reaction progress and improves reactant conversion but also helps maintain relatively high selectivity for the target product. Therefore, 7 mol/L AMeOH was used in subsequent experiments. 3.2.5 Influence of the reaction time and the catalyst loadings The effect of reaction time was further investigated. Reaction time is directly related to whether the hydrogenation reaction occurs fully. When measuring reactivity, we will avoid conducting the measurement at 100 % conversion and select an appropriate conversion range to ensure that the extent of the reaction can be independently and accurately quantified [46]. From the different reaction times (Fig. 8 a), it can be observed that the conversion rate shows a gradual upward trend with the reaction time increases from 0.5 h to 4 h. At 0.5 h, the conversion rate is relatively low, approximately 40 %, indicating that the reaction has not yet fully proceeded in the early stage. Over time, by around 3 h, the conversion rate approaches 100 %, suggesting that the reaction is essentially complete at this point. Extending the reaction time further to 4 h maintains the conversion rate at a high level without significant improvement, indicating that the reaction reaches equilibrium or near-complete consumption of reactants under the current conditions by 3 h. The selectivity remains relatively stable throughout the reaction process, consistently staying within the range of 91 % to 97 %. This demonstrates that the reaction system exhibits good selectivity for the target product, with a low extent of side reactions. The observed trend indicates that Ni-JKS-600 catalysts' superior selectivity stems from the inherent activity of its catalytic sites (e.g., Ni nanoparticles anchored on N-doped carbon), which efficiently hydrogenate imine intermediates, independent of reaction conversion effects. As shown in Fig. 8 b, N-benzylidenebenzylamine was the only intermediate detected by GC, and its percentage first increased from 0 to 1.5 h and then decreased from 1.5 to 4 h. Moreover, as the conversion rate increases, the selectivity does not show significant fluctuations, indicating that the reaction system maintains stable selectivity. From the different catalyst loadings (SI, Fig. S4 a), the following observations can be made, when the catalyst loading increases from 0 to 20 mg, the conversion rate undergoes significant changes. At 0 mg catalyst loading, almost no reaction occurs, with the conversion rate approaching 0. As the catalyst loading increases to 5 mg, the conversion rate begins to rise, reaching approximately 10 %. When the loading is further increased to 10 mg, the conversion rate shows a substantial improvement to around 25 %. At 20 mg loading, the conversion rate significantly rises to nearly 60 %. This indicates that the catalyst loading has a crucial impact on the reaction conversion rate, and increasing the catalyst amount effectively promotes the reaction, enhancing the degree of reactant conversion. The selectivity remains relatively stable across different catalyst loadings, consistently around 90 %. This suggests that varying the catalyst loading does not significantly negatively affect the selectivity toward the target product. In other words, changes in catalyst loading primarily influence the reaction rate and conversion rate, while their impact on selectivity is minimal. Both reaction time and catalyst loading have a significant influence on the conversion rate. Appropriately extending the reaction time and increasing the catalyst loading can effectively enhance the degree of reactant conversion. The selectivity remains relatively stable during variations in reaction time and catalyst loading, indicating that the reaction system exhibits good stability in selectivity toward the target product. This further demonstrates that the adopted reaction system and conditions effectively promote the desired reaction while well suppressing side reactions. 3.2.6 Kinetic analysis The reaction was carried out at different temperatures in the range of 100–130 ℃. The reaction temperature had a strong effect on the initial rate of the reaction and the initial rate was found to increase with increase in the reaction temperature. The hydrogenation of BN can be regarded as a first-order reaction [48]. Thedynamic equation is: dC dt = - k C Aftertheintegration: ln C 0 C t = k t Arrhenius equation: k = A e - E a RT lnk = - Ea R × 1 T + l n A Where C 0 is the initial concentration of the reactant, Ct is the concentration of the reactant at time t, and k is the rate constant. Ea represents the activation energy. R denotes the gas constant (8.314 J/(mol·K)). T is the absolute temperature. A is the pre-exponential factor. The values of reaction rate constant (k) at different temperatures (100–130 ℃) and constant benzonitrile concentration were calculated and Arrhenius plot (Fig. 9 ) for these values gave activation energy 53.08 kJ mol−1 for hydrogenation of benzonitrile. The decreased activation energy suggests that theNi-JKS-600 catalystsuccessfully lowers the reaction energy barrier, confirming its superior catalytic performance. 3.2.7 Comparison of the catalyst and stability of the catalyst The hydrogenation conditions of benzonitrile were selected, such as pressure, temperature, time, and solvent concentration. The best process conditions (2 MPa, 120 ℃, 3 h, 7 mol/L) were obtained, the conversion of benzonitrile was the highest (98.14 %), and the selectivity to benzylamine was the highest (97.08 %). Moreover, we then evaluated the conversion and selectivity of Ni-JKS-600 catalyst compared with other normally used commercially available precious metal catalysts, such as Ru/C, Pt/C, Pd/C, Ir/C, and Raney Ni. As shown in Fig. 10 , under the same reaction condition, except for Ir/C, other commercially available catalysts have high conversion for BN, but their selectivity for BA is not ideal. In addition, although the Raney nickel catalyst has an excellent catalytic effect, Raney nickel is easy to spontaneous combustion in the air, and there are safety risks in the use process. By further comparing the catalytic activity of Raney nickel and Ni-JKS-600 catalyst at low conversion rate, it was found that the conversion rate of benzylamine and the selectivity of benzylamine were higher than that of Raney nickel ( Fig. S7 ). The results showed that the Ni-JKS-600 catalyst had better catalytic activity. In addition, the catalyst also has good stability and recovery performance. ICP detection of reaction solution (0.22 μm nylon membrane filtration) showed Ni content < 0.05 %, and no significant leaching was confirmed ( Table S2 ). According to Fig. 11 , after three cycles of use, the activity of the catalyst showed good stability, and the catalyst is magnetic and easy to separate and recover. In conjunction with RJ Davis' discussion [47] (“Reaction Engineering Concepts for Catalytic transformation of Biorenewable Molecules”), catalyst deactivation can be caused by temporary deactivation of the active site by covering it with reaction intermediates or byproducts; Or impurity poisoning, where trace impurities in the reactants or solvents can lead to irreversible deactivation. 3.2.8 Substrate exploration Using selective hydrogenation of benzonitrile as the model reaction, the process conditions of the Ni-JKS-600 catalyst were successfully optimized. Extended experiments were carried out on several nitriles, and the data of target product, conversion rate, and selectivity were summarized in Table 1 . 4-fluorobenzylamine is widely used as an intermediate in the anti-allergy drug astimizole and the analgesic Flupirine. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the conversion of 4-fluorobenzonitrile is ＞99 %, and the selectivity of 4-fluorobenzylamine is 91 % (Table 1 entry 1). 4-chlorobenzylamine is an important organic compound and is mainly used as an intermediate in dyes. In the field of medicine, it is the raw material for the manufacture of drugs (Librium, phenacetin). It is also an important raw material for insecticides, herbicides, and fungicides. From the perspective of market capacity and demand trend, the demand for the 4-chlorobenzylamine industry has continued to rise in the past five years, and the market capacity reached 100 million yuan in 2022, occupying a certain proportion of the market share. This indicates a strong demand for 4-chlorobenzylamine applications in related fields, and the demand potential is expected to further increase in the next few years. Under the optimal reaction conditions, the conversion of 4-chloro-benzonitril is 98.70 %, and the selectivity of 4-chlorobenzylamine is 90.71 % (Table 1 entry 2). 4-methylbenzonitrile is widely used in organic synthesis, and it is also used in the coatings, rubber, and plastics industries. With the optimal reaction conditions, the conversion of 4-methylbenzonitrile is 98.79 %, and the selectivity of the product is 96.18 % (Table 1 entry 3). 4-methylbenzylamine is also an important intermediate in the synthesis of many chemicals. Most importantly, Ni-JKS-600 shows remarkable substrate applicability in several nitrile instances under optimal process conditions (Table 1, entry 4–10). It was suggested that the steric hindrance showed an influence on the substrate activity. The activity of 2-fluorobenzonitrile and 2-chlorobenzonitrile (Table 1, entries 7 and 8) with larger steric hindrances was much lower than that of 3-fluorobenzonitrile and 3-chlorobenzonitrile (Table 1, entries 4 and 5), due to the difficulty of the nitrile group in 2-Fluorobenzonitrile and 2-Chlorobenzonitrile in contact with the Ni site on the catalyst surface. And dehalogenation was not observed in this research. 3-Cyanopyridine and Piperonylonitrile showed great catalyst applicability, with conversion and selectivity > 95 % (Table 1, entries 9 and 10). These primary amines are important intermediates in medicine, pesticides, and dyes. Aromatic nitrile containing electron-donating groups (Table 1 entry 11) requires relatively harsh reaction conditions for better conversion. 3.2.9 The main reaction pathway of the hydrogenation of benzonitrile As shown in Fig. 12 , in the benzonitrile hydrogenation reaction, we would prefer to see benzonitrile (compound A) hydrogenated with 1 molecule of hydrogen to produce benzylimine (compound B), which reacts with 1 molecule of hydrogen to produce the target product benzylamine (compound C). At the same time, inevitably, benzylimine (compound B) and benzylamine (compound C) will condense to release 1 molecule of ammonia to form dibenzylimine (compound D) [6]. Comparing the experimental results of methanol and ammonia methanol as solvent, we speculated that under the action of ammonia methanol, due to the presence of ammonia atmosphere, the condensation reaction between benzylimine (compound B) and benzylamine (compound C) would be inhibited, which was conducive to more further hydrogenation reaction of benzylimine (compound B) to benzylamine (compound C) [18,48,49]. In the Ni-JKS-600 catalyst, metal nickel is the hydrogenation site of hydrogen, and they are easy to dissociate hydrogen. All these promoted the high selectivity of benzylamine in the benzonitrile hydrogenation reaction. 4 Conclusion In summary, we prepared an economical, green, and efficient bio-based nitrogen-doped carbon-supported non-noble metal nickel catalyst. Through the detailed characterization of the catalyst, it was found that the surface of the catalyst has abundant pore structure and nickel hydrogenation active sites which are conducive to hydrogenation reaction. The Ni-JKS-600 catalyst, with its unique graphene-encapsulated nickel structure and abundant porous architecture, not only ensures excellent catalyst stability but also provides efficient pathways for benzonitrile diffusion. This distinctive structure enables highly efficient hydrogenation of benzonitrile with both high conversion and selectivity under mild reaction conditions. The effects of reaction pressure, reaction temperature, and reaction time on the hydrogenation performance of the Ni-JKS-600 catalyst were optimized and analyzed. Under the optimal reaction conditions (2 MPa, 120 ℃, 3 h), the conversion of benzonitrile reached 98.14 % and the selectivity of benzylamine was 97.08 %, which was even comparable to that of commercial catalyst Raney Nickel. Ammonia-methanol as a solvent can effectively inhibit side reactions such as condensation and hydrolysis, showing high selectivity to benzylamine, and the Ni-JKS-600 catalyst is magnetic and easy to separate and recover. At the same time, chitin is a cheap biomass platform, which is derivative with a wide range of sources. In short, the catalyst has the advantages of low cost, simple preparation, mild reaction conditions, and great catalyst stability, which have obvious advantages in the future industrial production of benzylamine. coredata.dc:description: Benzylamine production from the hydrogenation of nitrile is attractive, but most of the catalysts are complicated and costly. In this paper, a simple synthesis of self-nitrogen-doped carbon-supported nickel biobased sustainable catalyst (Ni-JKS-600) for benzylamine hydrogenation with benzonitrile has been reported. The catalyst has high specific surface area, abundant micro-mesoporous structure and nickel hydrogenation active site. By optimizing the reaction conditions, a mild reaction condition (120 ℃, 2 MPa H2, 3 h) was determined, and it was found that the solvent had a significant effect on the selectivity of benzylamine, and the selectivity of benzylamine could reach 97.08 % when ammonia methanol was used as the solvent. Ni-JKS-600 catalyst is superior to precious metal catalysts (Ru, Pt, Ir, Pd) in aniline selectivity, and is comparable to Raney nickel catalyst, which shows its potential application in industrial production of amines. The catalyst uses cheap and widely available chitin as carbon and nitrogen source, and has the characteristics of green economy with simple preparation method and low cost. It is expected to replace precious metal catalyst for efficient production of benzylamine in the future.
